PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  Project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) is required in order to (i) help select 
target roads, (ii) prepare basic engineering designs, (iii) conduct ADB’s due diligence in financial, 
social and environmental areas, (iv) prepare required due diligence documents, and (iv) support 
early procurement. 
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The PPTA will cover engineering, economic, financial, social and environmental aspects, 
as well as procurement preparation and support. Engineering will be carried out in sufficient 
detail  to  carry  out  the  procurement  of  the  works.  The  major  outputs  and  activities  are 
summarized in Table 1.

3.  ADB has recruited consultants under MYA: TA8788 to advise Department of Rural 
Development (DRD) on a long-term sustainable approach to providing rural access.1 TA8788 
consultants and DRD will (i) define the CRRN, train local DRD staff in prioritizing projects for the 
pilot  areas  (excluding  projects  with  significant  negative  environmental  impacts  and/or 
resettlement requirements) and facilitate consultations carried out by DRD, (ii) select design 
standards, (iii) select trials and complementary measures to be piloted under the project, and (iv) 
draft a national rural roads and access strategy. Results will be available before the PPTA 
commences. 
 
4.  The UK Aid-funded Research for Community Access Program (ReCAP) is defining with 
DRD a program of assistance. DRD’s priority is to a review and upgrading of existing standards 
leading to a Low Volume Rural Road Design Manual, which is likely to include some trials work. 
ADB  is  in  discussions  with  ReCAP  and  DRD  to  enter  into  an  agreement  on  cooperation 
whereby  ReCAP  will  support  DRD  in  preparation  and  implementation  support  for  these 
measures, which will be integrated by the PPTA consultant into the project to be financed under 
the ADB loan.  
 
C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
5.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,030,000 equivalent, of which $1,000,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB's Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-Others). The government 
will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, provision of furnished office 
accommodation,  communications  (local  calls  and  internet  connection),  and  other  in-kind 
contributions. The detailed cost estimate is presented in Table 2.

D.  Consulting Services 
6.  The PPTA will be implemented over a period of 19 months (9 months project preparation 
followed by up to 10 months of procurement support) using a combination of a consulting firm 
and individual consultants. All consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
on  the  Use  of  Consultants  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  and  its  Borrowers  (2013,  as 
amended from time to time). To enable a quick start of works and continuity with the ongoing 
TA8788, an individual consultant in rural road management will be engaged to help DRD finalize 
the selection of roads and scope of other subcomponents. ADB will hire a consulting firm using 
quality- and cost-based selection (simplified technical proposal) with a quality to cost ratio of 
90:10. The firm will provide 16 months of international consultant input and 35 person-months of 
national consultant input. Finally, ADB will recruit individual environment, social management, 
and road safety specialists with expertise in the design of rural road programs in South or 
Southeast Asia region to implement a context-sensitive design approach. 
 
7.  The  consulting  firm  will  be  responsible  for  the  administration  of  workshop  training, 
seminars and conferences, and surveys under the project preparatory TA. Equipment and 
assets purchased under the work will adhere to ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2015, as 
amended from time to time), and upon completion of the project, the assets will be turned over 
to the executing agency.

8.  Under the consulting firm, the team leader (international, 7 person-months) and deputy 
team  leader  (national,  10  person-months)  will  coordinate  PPTA  activities,  conduct  the 
engineering study, prepare a detailed plan for implementation and other documents required for 
the project to be approved by ADB. The other engineers will assist the above two experts to 
complete  the  basic  designs  of  the  subprojects.  The  transport  economist  and  the  financial 
specialist  will  help  prepare  economic  and  financial  analyzes,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
guidelines. The procurement specialist will be responsible for procurement planning and support 
implementation.  
 
9.  The road management specialist (international, 3 person-months) will assist DRD in 
selecting the projects, identify access infrastructure, liaise with ReCAP on the definition of trials,

members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.  
management  specialist  (international,  5  person-months),  environment  and  road  safety 
specialists (international, 4 person-months each) will be responsible for recommending context-
sensitive design features, introducing a community participation framework, and developing

safeguard documents and social and poverty analysis, in accordance with ADB’s guidelines. 
They will work with the national gender development specialist (three person-months) to assess 
gender issues and develop gender-sensitive design features.  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
10.  The Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock and Irrigation will be the executing agency, and the 
Department of Rural Development will be the implementing agency. Disbursements under the 
TA will follow ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time).
